What is this art thou wouldst
teach me?
speaker: Hasan of Bassorah

utterance:
O Hasan, set the crucible
and apply the bellows.
speaker: the Persian

utterance: Hast thou any copper?
speaker: the Persian

speaker: Hasan of Bassorah

utterance:
Let us put this in the fire and make of it lumps of
gold.
speaker: Hasan of Bassorah

utterance:
My son, have
the Jinns made thee mad that thou wouldest go down
into the market with two ingots of gold in one day?
People will say these men practise alchemy, and the judges
will hear of us, and we shall lose our lives. If thou
wouldst learn this mystery let us go to thy house.
speaker: the Persian

utterance: O my father, what of the covenant of bread and salt that was made betwixt thee and me?
speaker: Hasan of Bassorah

utterance: O dog, does the like of me know of the bond of bread and salt? Of youths like thee I have slain a thousand save one, and thou shalt make up the thousand unless thou do sacrifice to fire.
speaker: Persian

utterance:
How can I ever
rely upon thee again?
speaker: Hasan of Bassorah

utterance:
O my son, but for sin there were no pardon. Indeed,
I did all these things to thee but to try thy patience.
speaker: Persian

utterance: O Master, whither goest thou?
speaker: Hasan of Bassorah

utterance:
I am bound for
the Mountain of Clouds, where is the elixir which we
use in alchemy.
speaker: Persian

utterance:
O Hasan, come, let us go
ashore.
speaker: Persian

utterance:
O Hasan, what
seest thou?
speaker: Persian

utterance:
I see clouds and mist
from east and west.
speaker: Hasan of Bassorah

utterance:
That is
neither clouds nor mist, but a vast and lofty mountain on
which the clouds split: it is for that I have brought thee
thither.
speaker: Persian

utterance:
What is
yonder palace?
speaker: Hasan of Bassorah

Lie down on this skin
and I will sew thee up therein. But the rukhs will
come to thee and carry thee up to the top of the
mountain. Take this knife with thee, and when the
birds have done flying and have set thee down, slit the
skin open and come forth. Then the birds will take
fright at thee and fly away; and thou shalt look down
131
from the top of the mountain and speak to me and do

speaker: Persian

utterance: What is there behind thee?
speaker: Persian

utterance:
This is what we
need. Make six bundles of the wood and throw them
down to me, for out of this wood do we do alchemy.
speaker: Persian

utterance:
Thou gallows bird, I
have all I wish of thee. Dwell there above, or throw
thyself down, as thou wilt.
speaker: Persian

utterance:
Here is a son of man; methinks it is the one that
Barham the Fire Worshipper brought here this year.
speaker: one of the maidens

utterance:
Yes, ladies, I am indeed that unhappy
one.
speaker: Hasan of Bassorah

utterance:
Bear
witness, sister, that this is my brother by covenant, and
I will die for his death and live for his life, joy for his
joy and mourn for his mourning.
speaker: Princesses

utterance: Sit thou in this hide.
speaker: Persian

utterance:
Hold thy hand,
cursed one! dog! traitor! that hast broken the bond
of bread and salt.
speaker: Hasan of Bassorah

utterance:
O Hasan, how
hast thou escaped? Thou art dearer to me than the
light of mine eyes.
speaker: Persian

utterance:
Go thou whither
thou wilt.
speaker: Hasan of Bassorah

utterance:
Rise,
Hasan, run to thy chamber and conceal thyself, but fear
not, no harm shall befall thee.
speaker: Princesses

utterance: How long shall we be absent from this place?
speaker: Princesses

utterance:
The time to come and to go and
to stay will be two months.
speaker: King

utterance:
We must be away for two
months, but, in the meanwhile, this house is thy house,
all the keys of it we leave with thee. But, O our
brother, by the bond of brotherhood we beseech thee in
very deed, open not the eighth door.
speaker: Princesses

utterance:
My sister had never told me not
to open this door unless there were behind it something
about which she would have none know. But I will
open it and find out what it is, even though within were
sudden death.
speaker: Hasan of Bassorah

utterance:
I
wonder to which of the Kings this palace belongeth,
or is it Many-Columned Iram whereof they tell,
for who among mortals can pretend to the like of
this?
speaker: Hasan of Bassorah

utterance:
O
King's daughters, it grows late, our land is afar and we
weary of this place. Come, then, let us depart to our
own country.
speaker: Princesses

utterance:
My sister forbade me open the door,
for she feared lest I should fall in love with one of
these damsels. Now, O Hasan, how shalt thou woo
and win her? Thou hast cast thyself into a bottomless
sea, and snared thyself in a net whence there is no
escape! I shall die desolate, and none shall know of
my death.
speaker: Hasan of Bassorah

utterance:
Tell me, what aileth thee,
O my brother, that I may do away with thy sorrow.
I will be thy ransom.
speaker: Princesses

utterance:
O my brother, what hath happened
to thee that thou speakest with tears? By our love as
brother and sister tell me what aileth thee, tell me thy
secret, nor hide aught of that which hath befallen thee
during our absence, for I am sorrowful because of thee.
speaker: Princesses

utterance:
I
fear, O my sister, if I tell thee thou wilt not help me to
win my wish, but wilt leave me to die in my pain.
speaker: Hasan of Bassorah

utterance:
Nay, I will not leave thee, though it
cost me my life.
speaker: Princesses

utterance:
Be of good cheer, O my
brother, for though it cost me my life, I will devise
means by which thou mayest wed her, if such be
the will of Allah Almighty. But keep the matter
from my sisters; tell it them not. If they question
thee of opening the forbidden door, say 'I opened it
not, but I was troubled at your absence and my loneliness
in yearning for you!'
speaker: Princesses

utterance:
Yes; this is
the right rede.
speaker: Hasan of Bassorah

utterance:
His sickness was caused by our leaving him
desolate, for the days we have been absent have seemed
to him more than a thousand years. Perchance, too, he
has been thinking of his mother, who may have been
weeping for him and mourning his loss day and night,
for when we were with him we were the means of
diverting his thoughts.
speaker: Princesses

utterance: 'Fore Allah, he is not to blame.
speaker: sisters

utterance:
O my
brother, show me the place where thou sawest the
maidens.'
speaker: Princesses

utterance:
Explain to me, O my
brother, how they came.'
speaker: Princesses

utterance:
What aileth thee, O my sister, that thou art pale
and troubled?
speaker: Hasan of Bassorah

utterance:
O my brother, this
lady is the daughter of one of the most powerful kings of
the Jinn. Her father ruleth men and Jinn, and wizards
and cohens, and chiefs of tribes and guards and countries
and cities and islands, and is immensely rich. Our
father is a Viceroy and one of his vassals, and none can
avail against him. And he hath given his daughters a
large tract of country, a year's journey in length and
breadth, girt about with a great, deep river. He hath
an army of women equal in courage to a thousand of the
bravest knights, and seven daughters who excel their
sisters in valour. The maidens who came with the
lady thou lovest are the ladies of her court, and their
feather raiment is the handiwork of the Jinn enchanters.
If thou wouldst wed this queen pay good heed to my
words. They come to this place on the first day of
every month, and when thou watchest them beware well
that they do not see thee or we shall lose our lives.
When they doff their dress, note which is the feather
suit of her thou lovest and take it, for it beareth her to
her country, and in taking it thou hast mastered her.
But beware lest she take it from thee by her wiles.
Then her companions will flee, and she will be at thy
mercy.
speaker: Princesses

utterance:
O king's
daughter, how cometh it that you harbour mortal men
and disclose to them our case and yours?
speaker: Princesses

utterance:
O king's daughter, this mortal
is perfect and will do thee no harm, for he loveth thee,
in sooth, he hath nearly died for love of thee.
speaker: Princesses

utterance:
Arise, go to her, and kiss
her hands and feet.
speaker: Princesses

utterance:
O Princess of fair ones, I took thee only that
I might be thy bondsman till the day of doom, and I ask
naught of thee but to take thee to wife after the law of
Allah. And when thou wilt I will take thee to my
country, and thou shalt have handmaidens of thine own,
and my mother shall do thee service.
speaker: Hasan of Bassorah

utterance:
What is the reason of thy tears? Which of us hath
vexed thee that thou art thus troubled?
speaker: Princesses

utterance:
He hath caught
a bird from the air, and would have you help him tame
her.
speaker: Princesses

utterance:
Do thou tell them, for I
cannot face them with these words.
speaker: Princesses

utterance: Where is she?
speaker: Princesses

utterance:
With him in such a
chamber.
speaker: Princesses

utterance: Describe her to us.
speaker: Princesses

utterance: Show her to us.
speaker: Princesses

utterance:
Indeed, he loveth thee with a
passionate love, and seeketh thee in marriage, wherefore
he came to thee in person. And he telleth us he hath
burnt thy feather raiment, or we had taken it from him.
speaker: Princesses

utterance:
What aileth
thee, O my lord?
speaker: Princesses

utterance:
Do as thou
wilt, for it behoveth thee to visit thy mother but see
thou visit us, though it be only once a year.
speaker: Princesses

utterance:
If aught grieve thee, beat the kettledrum and return
to us on the dromedaries.
speaker: Princesses

utterance:
Suffer her not to go out of the door, nor to look out
of the window, nor over the wall, for if aught of evil
befell her I should slay myself for her sake. Here is
her feather dress in a chest underground; watch over it
lest she find it and take it, for then she would fly away
with her children, and I should never hear of her again.
speaker: Hasan of Bassorah

utterance:
Have I lived with him
three years, and shall I never be allowed to go to the
bath?
speaker: Princesses

utterance:
O my daughter,
here we are strangers, and thy husband is abroad, but
I will heat thee water and wash thy head in the
Hammam-bath which is in the house.
speaker: Hasan's mother

utterance:
O Tohfah, why hast thou tarried
in the Hammam?
speaker: Lady Zubaydah

utterance:
O, my lady, I have
seen a marvel, never saw I its like among men or
women.
speaker: Tohfah the Lutanist

utterance: What was that?
speaker: Lady Zubaydah

utterance:
O,
my lady, I saw a damsel in the bath with her two little
boys like moons, eye never espied her like, neither hath
she her peer for beauty in the whole world. Surely, if
the Commander of the Faithful knew of her he would
slay her husband, Hasan of Bassorah, and take her from
him.
speaker: Tohfah the Lutanist

utterance:
Woe is thee, Tohfah, if
she be not as thou sayest, for then, indeed, will I bid
strike off thy head. But I must needs look on her.
speaker: Lady Zubaydah

utterance:
Go to
the Wazir's house and bring me the damsel who
dwelleth there, also her two children and the old woman.
Haste, and tarry not.
speaker: Lady Zubaydah

utterance: Who is at the door?
speaker: the old woman

utterance:
Masrur, servant of the Com-
mander of the Faithful.
speaker: Masrur

utterance:
Lady Zubaydah, queen-wife of the Commander of the
Faithful, summoneth thee and thy son's wife and children
to her, for she hath been told of the lady's beauty.
speaker: Masrur

utterance:
O, my lord Masrur, we are
foreign folk, and the girl's husband, who is away from
home, hath bidden me not let her go forth in his absence,
therefore I beseech thee, ask me not this thing.
speaker: the old woman

utterance:
O, my lady, there is naught to fear
therein or I would not ask it of you.
The Lady
Zubaydah desireth to see her, and after that she may
return.
speaker: Masrur

utterance:
Wilt thou
not uncover thy face that I may look on it?
speaker: Lady Zubaydah

utterance:
O liege lady of
fair ones, what arts knowest thou?
speaker: Lady Zubaydah

utterance:
O, my lady, I have a dress of feathers, and if I put it
on thou wouldst see one of the fairest of fashions and
wouldst marvel thereat.
speaker: Princesses

utterance: Where is this dress of thine?
speaker: Lady Zubaydah

utterance:
It is
with my husband's mother; seek it of her.
speaker: Princesses

utterance:
O, my lady, the pilgrimess! O, my mother! fetch us the feather dress, afterwards thou
mayest take it back again.
speaker: Lady Zubaydah

utterance:
O, my lady, this damsel is a liar. Hast thou ever seen
any woman with a feather dress, such belongeth only to
birds?
speaker: the old woman

utterance:
As thou livest, O my
lady, she hath a feather dress of mine. It is in a chest
buried in a store cupboard in the house.
speaker: Princesses

utterance: O, my mother, I
speaker: Lady Zubaydah

utterance: Take this key and go to the house, and enter the store cupboard there, in the middle of which thou wilt find a chest buried. Take the chest out, break it open, and bring me the feather dress therein.
speaker: Lady Zubaydah

utterance: Is this thy dress of feathers?
speaker: Lady Zubaydah

utterance: Yes, O my lady.
speaker: the damsel

utterance: Is this goodly, O my ladies?
speaker: the damsel

utterance: Yes, O Princess AHLI of the Fair! All thou dost is goodly.
speaker: my ladies

utterance: And this, O my mistresses, that I am about to do is better yet.
speaker: the damsel

utterance: This is indeed, a rare and outlandish fashion! Never saw we its like. Wilt thou not come down to us that we may enjoy thy beauty, O fairest of the fair?
speaker: Lady Zubaydah

utterance: Far be it from me, to come back to the past.
speaker: the damsel

utterance: O my lady, O mother of my husband, it grieveth me to part from thee. When thy son returneth, and longeth, and wearieth after me, tell him to come to me in the islands of Wak.
speaker: the damsel

utterance: If thou hadst told me that this would happen I would not have gain- said thee. And had I known she was of the Flying Jinn I would not have allowed her to don the dress. But now, words profit nothing, so do thou acquit me of offence against thee.
speaker: Lady Zubaydah

utterance: Thou art acquitted.
speaker: the old woman

utterance: O my son, may Allah require thee their loss! These are their three tombs.
speaker: Hasan's mother

utterance: Except thou tell me the truth I will strike off thy head and kill myself.
speaker: Hasan of Bassorah

utterance: O my son, do not such deed, put up thy sword and sit down till I tell thee what hath passed.
speaker: Hasan's mother

utterance: Tell thy son, when he cometh to thee and the nights of severance shall be longsome to him, and he craveth reunion and meeting to see, and whenas the winds of love and longing shake him dolefully, let him fare to me in the islands of Wak.
speaker: Hasan's wife

utterance: There is no Majesty and there is no Might save in Allah, the Glorious, the Great! Put forth thy hand to Heaven, and when thou reach thither, then shalt thou win to thy wife.
speaker: Princesses

utterance: O my brother, be of good cheer, keep thy eyes cool and clear and be patient, so shalt thou win thy will for whoso hath patience and waiteth, that he seeketh attaineth.
speaker: Princesses

utterance: O daughter of my brother, if thou be in want of aught or if aught trouble thee, or if thou stand in any need, cast off these perfumes upon fire naming my name, and I will be with thee and will do thy desire.
speaker: Abd al-Kaddus

utterance: Return us some answer, for our hearts are rent in sunder.
speaker: Princesses

utterance: Be ye silent!
speaker: Abd al-Kaddus

utterance: O my son, hearten thy heart and rejoice in the winning of thy wish: take courage and follow me.
speaker: Abd al-Kaddus

utterance: Sit at the door till I return, and beware lest thou open it and enter.
speaker: Abd al-Kaddus

utterance: Mount!
speaker: Abd al-Kaddus

utterance: O my son, take this scroll and go whither the steed will carry thee. When thou seest him stop at the door of a cavern like this, alight and throw the reins over the saddle-bow and let him go. He will enter the cavern, but enter not with him; tarry at the door five days without wearying of waiting. On the sixth day will come forth to thee a black Shaykh clad in sable, with a long white beard. Kiss his hands, seize his skirt, and lay it on thy head, and weep before him, till he take pity on thee and ask thee what thou would'st have. When he saith: 'What is thy want?' give him this scroll, which he will take without speaking, and go in and leave thee. Wait at the door another five days without wearying, and on the sixth day expect him. And if he come out to thee himself, know that thy wish will be won, but if one of his pages come, know that he meaneth to kill thee; and thus thy story will end.
speaker: Abd al-Kaddus

utterance: Know, O my son, that the Islands of Wak are seven in number, peopled by a mighty host of women, and the Inner Isles by Satans, Marids, Warlocks, and various tribes of the Jinn. And no man once entering this land hath ever returned. Will nothing serve thee but that thou must make the journey?
speaker: Abd al-Kaddus

utterance: Nothing! I only ask thy prayers for help and aidance.
speaker: Hasan of Bassorah

utterance: I have in this letter given a strict charge concerning thee to Abu al- Ruwaysh, son of Bilkis, daughter of Muin, for he is my Shaykh and my teacher, and all men and Jinn humble themselves to him and stand in awe of him.
speaker: Abd al-Kaddus

utterance: What wantest thou, O my son?
speaker: Abu al- Ruwaysh

utterance: I accept, O elder of elders!
speaker: Ifrit

utterance: Mount the shoulders of this Ifrit, Dahnash the Flyer, but when he heaveth thee heaven- wards, and thou hearest the angels glorifying God, have a care lest thou do the like, or thou and he will both perish.
speaker: Abu al- Ruwaysh

utterance: O Hasan, after faring with thee all day, to-morrow at peep of dawn he will set thee down in a land white like unto camphor, whereupon walk ten days by thyself till thou come to the gate of a city. This enter and inquire for the King, and when thou comest to his presence, salute him with the salaam and kiss his hand, then give him this scroll and consider well whatso he shall counsel thee.
speaker: Abu al- Ruwaysh

utterance: To hear is to obey.
speaker: Hasan of Bassorah

utterance: O Hasan, thou comest to me, seeking to enter the Islands of Wak. I would send thee thither this very day, but that by the way are many perils and wolds full of terrors, yet have patience and naught save fair shall befall thee. Presently there will come to us ships from the Islands of Wak, and the first that shall arrive I will send thee aboard her, and give thee in charge to the sailors, who will bear thee thither. As soon as thou comest ashore, thou wilt see a multitude of wooden benches about the beach choose thee one, and crouch under it and stir not. When night sets in, thou wilt see an army of women flocking about the goods landed from the ship, and one will sit down on the bench under which thou art hiding. Wherefore put forth thy hand and take hold of her and implore her protection. If she give thee pro- tection, thou wilt regain thy wife and children; if not, mourn for thyself, and give up all hope of life.
speaker: Hassun

utterance: Take this youth with thee so that none may know of him save thee, and carry him to the Islands of Wak.
speaker: Hassun

utterance: Be of good cheer, keep thine eyes cool and clear, take courage and return to thy hiding-place till the coming night, and Allah shall do as he will.
speaker: the merchant-woman

utterance: Have no fear whatsoever.
speaker: Shawahi

utterance: Glory be to God, who hath made thee appeal to me, for hadst thou appealed to any other thou would'st have lost thy life. But know, O my son, thy wife is not here, but in the seventh of the Islands of Wak, and between us and it is seven months' journey. From here we go to an island called the Land of Birds, wherein, for the loud crying of the birds and the flapping of their wings, one cannot hear other speak. From this country we come to another, the Land of Wild Beasts, where for roaring of lions, howling of wolves, laughing of hyaenas, and crying of other beasts of prey, we shall hear naught. The next is the Land of the Jann, where our eyes are blinded by the fires, the sparks and smoke from their mouths, and our ears deafened by their groan- ing. And after this we come to a huge mountain and running river close to the Isles of Wak. And on the bank of the river is another mountain, called Mount Wak, named thus by reason of a tree that bears fruits like heads of the sons of Adam.
speaker: Shawahi

utterance: O Hasan, would to heaven I had never known thee! This woman is none other than the eldest daughter of the Supreme King, she who ruleth over all the Islands of Wak. It is impossible for thee to obtain her, as between her and thee the distance is as that between earth and heaven. So return whence thou camest lest our lives be lost.
speaker: Shawahi

utterance: O my son, tell me which of the maidens pleaseth thee and I will give her thee instead of thy wife, and thou canst say that thy wife and children are dead, for if thou fall into the King's hand I have no means of delivering thee.
speaker: Shawahi

utterance: Be of good cheer, and keep thine eyes cool and clear, and put away trouble from thy thought, for I will risk my life for thee until thou attain thine aim or I die.
speaker: Shawahi

utterance: O Queen of the Age and the Time, I have a favour to crave of thee and I fain would discover it to thee, that thou mayest help me to accomplish it, and but for my confidence that thou wilt not gainsay me, therein I would not expose it to thee.
speaker: Shawahi

utterance: What is thy need? Expound it to me and I will accomplish it to thee, for I and my kingdom and troops are all at thy command.
speaker: Nur al-Huda

utterance: O ill-omened beldam, art thou come to such a pass that thou carriest men with thee into the Islands of Wak? But for thy claim on me I would make both him and thee die the foulest of deaths. Go and bring him hither that I may see him.
speaker: Nur al-Huda

utterance: Rise, speak with the Queen, O wight, whose last hour is at hand.
speaker: Shawahi

utterance: She would not have spoken thus, if she had not desired thee, nor acquainted thee with her abiding place.
speaker: Nur al-Huda

utterance: O mistress of Kings and asylum of prince and pauper, oppress me not, but have compassion on me and aid me to regain my wife and children.
speaker: Hasan of Bassorah

utterance: I have compassion on thee, and am resolved to show thee in review all the maidens in the city and in the provinces. If thou discover among them thy wife I will deliver her to thee, but if thou know her not, I will put thee to death and crucify thee over the old woman's door.
speaker: Nur al-Huda

utterance: Verily he hath entered our land, and eaten of our meat, wherefore he hath a claim upon us, the more especially since I promised him to bring him in company with thee; and thou knowest that parting is a grievous ill and severance hath power to kill, especially separation from children. Now he hath seen all our women save only thyself, so do thou show him thy face.
speaker: Shawahi

utterance: How can he be my husband and have had children by me, that I should show him my face?
speaker: Nur al-Huda

utterance: In very sooth this Queen is either my wife or else the likest of all folk to my wife.
speaker: Hasan of Bassorah

utterance: This stranger is either Jinn-mad or out of his mind, for he saith I am his wife.
speaker: Nur al-Huda

utterance: What is it in thy wife that resembleth me?
speaker: Nur al-Huda

utterance: All that is in thee of beauty and loveliness, elegance and amorous grace. Thou art her very self in thy way of speaking, in the fairness of thy favour, and the brilliancy of thy brow.
speaker: Hasan of Bassorah

utterance: Carry him back to the place where he tarried with thee till I examine into this affair, for he is a manly man, and forgotteth not friend or lover.
speaker: Nur al-Huda

utterance: Thy sister inviteth thee to visit her. And,
speaker: Nur al-Huda

utterance: I swear that if my sister prove to be his wife, I will not hinder him from taking her and the children to his own country.
speaker: Nur al-Huda

utterance: Verily, I am beholden to my sister, and have failed in my duty in not visiting her, but I will do so forthwith.
speaker: Manar al-Sana

utterance: Thy sister, Queen Nur al-Huda, biddeth thee clothe thy two sons in the coats of mail she made for them and send them to her by me.
speaker: Shawahi

utterance: O mother, I tremble when thou namest my children, for from the time of their birth none hath looked on their faces, neither Jinn, nor man, nor woman.
speaker: Manar al-Sana

utterance: Dost thou fear for them from thy sister? Indeed, the Queen would be wroth with thee if thou disobeyed her. And, O my daughter, thou knowest my tenderness and love for thee and thy children. I will take them under my care, so be of cheerful heart and send them her.
speaker: Shawahi

utterance: If I bring him wilt thou reunite him with his children? Or if they prove not his wilt thou pardon him and restore him to his own country?
speaker: Shawahi

utterance: This shall never be ; no, never; for if they be not his children I will slay him and strike off his neck with my own hand.
speaker: Nur al-Huda

utterance: Go with this crone and fetch me the youth who is in her house.
speaker: Nur al-Huda

utterance: O our father!
speaker: Nasir and Mansur

utterance: Arise! fly for thy life. But that I swore no evil should betide thee if thy tale proved true, I would slay thee with mine own hand.
speaker: Nur al-Huda

utterance: O my daughter, I have had a dream which maketh me fear that sorrow will betide thee where thou goest.
speaker: the King

utterance: What didst thou see in thy dream, O my father?
speaker: Manar al-Sana

utterance: I dreamt that I entered a secret hoard where was great store of moneys, jewels, jacinths, and other riches. But naught pleased me save seven bezels, which were the finest things there. And I chose the smallest of the seven, for it was the finest and most lustrous.
